channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Six surgeons general write in an op-ed: It’s our duty to warn the nation about RFK Jr.
item.description: We took an oath to declare dangers when we found them. We’re doing that again today.

item.title: Supreme Court appears deeply skeptical of Colorado law that bans conversion therapy for gay and transgender minors
item.description: A majority of justices appeared sympathetic to an evangelical therapist whose attorney argued that the state ban infringes on the therapist’s free-speech rights to counsel religious teens dealing with their sexual orientation and gender dysphoria in ways she said are consistent with biblical teachings.

item.title: Federal workers are not entitled to back pay after shutdown, White House budget office argues in memo
item.description: The top lawyer at the Office of Management and Budget argued in a draft memo obtained by The Washington Post that a law Congress passed and President Donald Trump signed in 2019 does not guarantee back pay to furloughed workers, ratcheting up tensions in Washington over the week-long shutdown.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Twin teens don’t want to meet their widowed parent’s new love
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Twin teens don’t want to meet their widowed parent’s new love

item.title: ICE has kept most offices open during the government shutdown — but not the one inspecting conditions at detention centers
item.description: Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s entire Office of Detention Oversight has been placed on furlough, despite surging numbers of detainees. The contrast between the office’s temporary closure and the ongoing immigration crackdown highlights how the Trump administration’s priorities have steered ICE’s operations during the funding impasse.

item.title: Portland is the topic of today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Tom Sietsema says goodbye after 25 years. And we finally reveal what our food critic looks like.
item.description: He’s written hundreds of restaurant reviews and thousands of reader Q&As and somehow never had his face appear online before now. Far from retiring, Tom plans to cook more and stay connected with fellow food enthusiasts -- and has some suggestions for getting more out of your restaurant experience.

item.title: National Guard. Oct. 7 anniversary. Pam Bondi. Covid shots. Everest rescue. TikTok addiction. Food critic reveal. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Nobel in physics awarded to scientists showing quantum mechanics on a macro scale
item.description: John Clarke, Michel Devoret and John Martinis shared the prize for demonstrating quantum mechanics on a new scale, used in today’s phones, computer, cameras and fiber optic cables.

item.title: Trump slashed university funding. Here are six key drugs that relied on it.
item.description: The Post examined six major drugs tied to federally funded research, which is now under threat at universities nationwide.

item.title: These photos show what it looks like in the world’s data center capital
item.description: These photos show what it looks like in the world’s data center capital

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Couple’s arguments can end only when boyfriend decides he’s done
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Couple’s arguments can end only when boyfriend decides he’s done

item.title: Supreme Court won’t hear Ghislaine Maxwell’s appeal
item.description: Maxwell, an associate of deceased financier Jeffrey Epstein, was convicted of sex trafficking in 2021.

item.title: Nothing is real on this new app in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: VA spends billions on dubious, even fraudulent disabilities benefits
item.description: Military veterans are swamping the U.S. government with dubious disability claims — including cases of brazen fraud totaling tens of millions of dollars — that are exploiting the country’s sacred commitment to compensate those harmed in the line of duty, according to a Washington Post investigation.

item.title: National Guard. Gaza talks. Unusual shutdown. Supreme Court. Disability benefits. Ozempic at Costco. SNL. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Nobel Prize for medicine awarded for discoveries about the immune system
item.description: Mary E. Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell and Shimon Sakaguchi shared the Nobel Prize for fundamental discoveries in how the immune system keeps itself in check.

item.title: Judge temporarily blocks California National Guard members from deploying to Oregon
item.description: U.S. District Judge Karin J. Immergut said the government appeared to be directly defying her previous order by instead sending members of California’s Guard. She broadened the terms of her restraining order to prohibit the administration from sending any state’s National Guard troops to Oregon. Immergut, a Trump appointee confirmed to the bench in 2019, issued a new, broader order Sunday to prohibit the administration from sending any state’s National Guard troops under federal control to Oregon.

item.title: Tensions spike in Chicago, Portland as Trump faces legal challenges over troop use
item.description: California will sue the Trump administration, Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) said, over plans to send 300 state National Guard troops to Oregon.

item.title: They grew up unvaccinated. After age 18, they faced a choice.
item.description: Some who received little to no vaccination in childhood sought out the shots themselves in adulthood — and risked family relationships.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Trump plan would limit Social Security disability benefits for older Americans
item.description: The Trump administration is preparing a plan that will make it harder for older Americans to qualify for Social Security disability payments, part of an overhaul of the federal safety net for poor, older and disabled people that could result in hundreds of thousands of people losing benefits, according to people familiar with the plans.

item.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump from deploying troops in Portland
item.description: Oregon officials had challenged President Donald Trump’s move to send troops to the state’s largest city, calling it “patently unlawful.”

item.title: Medical Mysteries: A high-schooler with hip pain, then a life-threatening diagnosis
item.description: One doctor told her the hip pain was a twisted pelvis. Another said the pain was just in her head.

item.title: This billionaire Trump ally and his son are building an unprecedented media empire
item.description: Larry and David Ellison’s holdings span movies, TV networks, CBS and soon a stake in TikTok, in a paradigm shifting portfolio with huge influence.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Many American Jews sharply critical of Israel on Gaza, Post poll finds
item.description: Most said Israel is committing war crimes — and 39 percent said genocide — while often distinguishing between the country and its leadership.

item.title: Sanae Takaichi is set to become Japan’s first female prime minister
item.description: The new leader will take the helm of the world’s fourth-largest economy at a time of unusual political instability, rising prices and increasing regional tensions.

item.title: Justice Kavanaugh assassination plotter sentenced to eight years in prison
item.description: Nicholas Roske, 29, had flown across the country, with a gun packed in a suitcase, intending to break into the justice’s Maryland home to kill him. The punishment was 22 years less than the minimum of 30 years sought by prosecutors.

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs sentenced to 50 months in prison
item.description: The judge will also fine Combs $500,000, and impose five years of supervised release once he completes his sentence.

item.title: Hamas accepts Trump’s plan to end Israel’s war in Gaza but with conditions
item.description: The plan aims to secure the release of Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip and end a two-year conflict that has reduced much of the enclave to rubble.

item.title: U.S. kills four more alleged drug smugglers near Venezuela, Hegseth says
item.description: Questions remain as to the legal justification underpinning the administration’s ongoing attacks targeting Latin American drug cartels.

item.title: Democrat Abigail Spanberger holds wide lead in Virginia governor’s race, Post-Schar School poll finds
item.description: Spanberger leads Republican Winsome Earle-Sears by double digits in the contest for governor, according to a Washington Post-Schar School poll of Virginia voters, picking up strong support from independent voters as well as those who are worried about the state’s job market.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: How do I handle my mother-in-law correcting my kids?
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: How do I handle my mother-in-law correcting my kids?

item.title: Sean “Diddy” Combs to be sentenced and is expected to speak in court for first time since his arrest. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: Prosecutors want the music producer to be imprisoned for more than 11 years following his conviction in the prostitution case, arguing at trial earlier this year that he used beatings, blackmail and drugs to abuse two girlfriends.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Blurb: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: CBS News to name Bari Weiss, a frequent critic of mainstream media, as its top editor
item.description: The newly formed media giant Paramount Skydance will acquire the Free Press, an online publication, and install its founder as editor in chief, according to two people familiar with the matter. The move heralds a new era at the 98-year-old broadcast network, whose corporate parents had sought to address the Trump administration’s allegations of liberal bias.

item.title: U.S. monthly jobs report won’t be released today due to the shutdown. Here’s why the data was much anticipated.
item.description: Three days into the government shutdown, it’s increasingly unclear where the U.S. economy is headed — not because of a direct hit from the federal closures, but a lack of official data.

item.title: Senate votes. Abortion pill. Trump and colleges. Manchester attack. Balin Miller. AI toxins. Taylor Swift. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Taylor Swift’s new album: A guide to the songs everyone is talking about
item.description: “The Life of a Showgirl,” which dropped Friday, is an ode to the superstar’s life behind the scenes on her record-breaking Eras Tour. And it has some eyebrow-raising lyrics.

item.title: How to live to 117? Researchers find clues in the world’s oldest woman.
item.description: A new study offers insights about what made Maria Branyas Morera exceptional — and what it could mean for the rest of us.

item.title: U.S. in ‘armed conflict’ with drug cartels, Trump tells Congress
item.description: The Trump administration is seeking legal justification for strikes on what it has claimed are Venezuelan drug traffickers at sea. Some lawmakers and legal experts have said the notification is dubious cover for what have been unlawful military strikes on alleged civilian criminals.

item.title: The Trump administration quietly approved a new abortion drug, infuriating the right
item.description: The FDA has little power to reject generic versions of approved drugs, but that hasn’t stopped an outcry from abortion opponents.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Parents blatantly favored brother, so all elder care is on him
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Parents blatantly favored brother, so all elder care is on him

item.title: Senior government officials privately warn federal agencies against firings during shutdown
item.description: Senior officials have quietly counseled several agencies against firing employees while the government is shut down — as President Donald Trump has suggested he will — warning the strategy may violate appropriations law, according to two people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Know your halftime shows in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: We asked 1,000 Americans who they blame for the shutdown. Here’s what they said.
item.description: The Post’s poll finds significantly more Americans blame President Donald Trump and congressional Republicans for the shutdown than Democrats, though many say they are not sure. A large majority support Democrats’ call to extend federal health insurance subsidies in general, though just under half support the party demanding this if it extends the government shutdown.

item.title: Attack at synagogue on Yom Kippur leaves two dead in England
item.description: Police officers shot a suspect who had rammed a car into some victims and stabbed others outside the synagogue in Manchester, police said.

item.title: Shutdown deadlock. Lie detector tests. Trump firings. Gaza flotilla. Jane Goodall. Warm October. Living longer. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.
